item.title: HIV care | Lenacapavir was the breakthrough drug in 2024 - Deccan Herald
item.description:
Lenacapavir: A Breakthrough Drug for HIV Treatment Approved in 2024

Publication Date: December 2024 Source: Gilead Sciences

A significant breakthrough in treating HIV has occurred with the FDA's approval of lenacapavir, a new medication that utilizes a unique injection method for individuals with multidrug-resistant HIV.

  • Lenacapavir has been described as the ‘2024 Breakthrough of the Year’ by the journal Science.
  • This drug represents a pivotal step toward diminishing the impact of HIV/AIDS globally.
  • The introduction of lenacapavir could help achieve the UN Sustainable Development Goal 3 for eliminating HIV/AIDS as a public health threat.
  • Clinical trials showed that 99.9% of participants in the lenacapavir group did not acquire HIV.
  • Despite its effectiveness, there are concerns about the cost and accessibility of lenacapavir, particularly in low- and middle-income countries.
  • Gilead has signed agreements to produce affordable versions of lenacapavir in resource-limited countries.
“Lenacapavir was highly effective at reducing HIV infections among trial participants: 99.9 percent of participants did not acquire HIV in the lenacapavir group.”

In conclusion, the emergence of lenacapavir is a major step forward in the global fight against HIV, offering new hope for effective management of the disease while highlighting the need for continued research and equitable healthcare policies.

item.title: Vitamin D in winters: Ensuring proper growth for your baby during pregnancy - The Times of India
item.description:
Vitamin D in winters: Ensuring proper growth for your baby during pregnancy

Publication Date: TBD | Source: Times of India

Vitamin D is crucial for the development of babies during pregnancy, particularly in winter months when sunlight exposure is limited.

  • Winter poses a challenge for pregnant women to get sufficient Vitamin D due to less sunlight.
  • Vitamin D is important for the development of the baby's bones and immune system.
  • Prenatal supplementation of Vitamin D is recommended, especially in areas with limited sun exposure.
"Adequate Vitamin D levels are essential for the overall health of both the mother and the baby."

Ensuring proper intake of Vitamin D during winter is vital for pregnant women to promote healthy fetal development and prevent deficiency-related issues.

item.title: 20-minute workout guide for women to get rid of fat around waist - The Times of India
item.description:
20-Minute Workout Guide for Women to Get Rid of Fat Around Waist

Publication Date: Jan 1, 2025 | Source: Times of India

Excess fat around the waist poses health risks like heart disease and diabetes. This workout guide provides effective exercises for women.

  • Warm-up: 3 minutes of light cardio.
  • Standing side crunches: 2 minutes targeting obliques.
  • Plank hold: 2 minutes for core strength.
  • Bicycle crunches: 3 minutes for effective waist slimming.
  • Mountain climbers: 3 minutes for calorie burn.
  • Cool down and stretch: 1 minute to promote flexibility.
“Fat deposition in the waist is linked to health risks like heart disease, diabetes, and hormonal imbalances. Regular exercise can help women strengthen their core and improve overall well-being.”

This 20-minute routine is designed to fit easily into busy schedules while addressing key health concerns for women.

item.title: Health News Live January 1, 2025 : New study reveals each cigarette shortens life by 20 minutes; women are at greater risk - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Health News Live January 1, 2025: New Study Reveals Each Cigarette Shortens Life by 20 Minutes; Women at Greater Risk

Publication Date: January 1, 2025 Source: Hindustan Times

A new study indicates that each cigarette shortens life by 20 minutes, with women at a higher risk than men.

  • A fresh study indicates that each cigarette smoked reduces life by 20 minutes, with men losing 17 and women 22 minutes.
“Each cigarette shortens life by 20 minutes.”

The findings highlight the significant health risks associated with smoking, particularly for women.

item.title: New study reveals each cigarette shortens life by 20 minutes; women are at greater risk - Hindustan Times
item.description:
New Study Reveals Each Cigarette Shortens Life by 20 Minutes; Women Are at Greater Risk

Date: Jan 01, 2025 | Source: Hindustan Times

A fresh study indicates that each cigarette smoked reduces life by 20 minutes, affecting men and women differently, with men losing 17 minutes and women 22 minutes.

  • Every cigarette shortens life by approximately 20 minutes.
  • A pack of 20 cigarettes can shorten life by nearly 7 hours.
  • Men lose 17 minutes for each cigarette, while women lose 22 minutes.
  • Quitting smoking can significantly improve longevity—smokers who quit can prevent substantial losses of life over time.
"A person smoking 10 cigarettes per day who quits smoking on the 1st of January 2025 could prevent the loss of a full day of life by the 8th of January, a week by the 20th of February, and a month by the 5th of August."

The study reveals alarming statistics about the impact of smoking on life expectancy and emphasizes the importance of quitting smoking for health benefits.

item.title: Common Cough Syrup Ingredient Could Treat a Serious Lung Disease - SciTechDaily
item.description:
Common Cough Syrup Ingredient Could Treat a Serious Lung Disease

Publication Date: 18 December 2024 | Source: Science Translational Medicine

A common ingredient in many over-the-counter cough syrups, dextromethorphan, may hold promise as a treatment for lung fibrosis—a condition associated with various serious health issues. Researchers from EMBL Heidelberg have identified dextromethorphan as a potential therapy for lung fibrosis, revealing its ability to reduce lung fibrosis by interfering with collagen production.

Key Points:

  • Lung fibrosis results in scarring and stiffness of lung tissue, causing breathing difficulties.
  • The WHO estimates that 761,000 people suffer from lung fibrosis in Europe, with significant health impacts.
  • Dextromethorphan was screened among FDA-approved drugs for its anti-fibrotic properties.
  • Preclinical tests on mouse models and human lung tissue show promising results.
  • Plans for phase II clinical trials are underway to investigate its efficacy in humans.
“After learning that lung fibrosis has no cure available, I wanted to discover novel drugs for this condition,” said Muzamil Majid Khan, EMBL research associate and the paper’s first author.

This research could potentially lead to new treatments for lung fibrosis, highlighting the therapeutic potential of existing medications.

item.title: New Year resolutions: Simple tips for heart health - Onmanorama
item.description:
New Year Resolutions for Heart Health

Published: January 01, 2025

Source: Unknown

The New Year presents an opportunity to set resolutions that can enhance heart health and overall well-being. While many people plan to eat healthier or quit unhealthy habits, the challenge often lies in maintaining these commitments. Here are some practical resolutions for a healthier heart that should be followed year-round.

  • Avoid prolonged sitting: Reduce sitting time to improve heart health; take walks every two hours if your job requires long periods of sitting.
  • Healthy diet: Incorporate vegetables, pulses, chicken, eggs, dairy, and grains into your diet to lower heart disease and diabetes risks.
  • Avoid sugary drinks: Cut back on sugary beverages and reduce sugar in tea and coffee to prevent health issues.
  • Good sleep: Aim for 7-8 hours of sleep to reduce stress and heart problems.
  • Reduce usage of phone: Spend less time on mobile devices and more time enjoying nature to combat loneliness and anxiety.
  • Quit smoking and drinking: Abstaining can lower blood pressure and improve life quality.
  • Regular health checkups: Ensure regular health screenings even without a family history of heart disease for early detection and intervention.

Implementing these resolutions can vastly improve your heart health and contribute to a fulfilling life throughout the year.

item.title: Health alert issued over deadly mosquito-borne virus in southeast Australia - Social News XYZ
item.description:
Health Alert Issued Over Deadly Mosquito-Borne Virus in Southeast Australia

Date: December 31, 2024

Source: Social News XYZ

Health authorities in Victoria, Australia, have issued a warning following the identification of a human case of the Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus.

  • First human case of JE virus reported in Victoria this summer.
  • Health officials advise precautions against mosquito bites.
  • The JE virus can lead to severe illness, including brain infections.
  • Children and the elderly are at higher risk of severe illness.
"The risk of mosquito-borne diseases remains high in the coming weeks. Taking measures to avoid mosquito bites is critical to protect against infections." - Christian McGrath, Acting Chief Health Officer

This health alert underscores the importance of public awareness and preventive measures as Australia enters the mosquito season.

item.title: Unlock your healthiest self in 2025: How much daily walking is really enough? - Irish Star
item.description:
How Much You Should Walk Every Day to Be Your Healthiest Self

Published: Not specified Source: Irish Star

The article discusses how many steps one should aim to walk each day to maintain good health, especially as people set their resolutions for the New Year. It emphasizes that a target of 10,000 steps, or about four to five miles, is commonly recommended for health benefits.

  • The ideal walking distance depends on various personal factors like weight, health goals, fitness level, and existing conditions.
  • It's advisable for beginners to start slowly with shorter distances and to gradually increase their walking as they become comfortable.
  • Walking more can assist with weight loss; burning approximately 300 to 400 calories daily can lead to losing one pound per week if combined with a balanced diet.
  • Distributing walking throughout the day can make the goal more achievable, such as taking brisk walks at different times rather than all at once.
  • Having a walking companion can motivate individuals to reach their daily goals while enjoying each other's company.
"With a target of 10,000 steps a day, you can burn approximately 300 to 400 calories, leading to potential weight loss over time."

In conclusion, walking is a simple, cost-effective way to improve health and well-being, making it an ideal New Year's resolution.

item.title: Sleep apnea? Neuro implants promise good night’s rest - The Times of India
item.description:
Sleep apnea? Neuro implants promise good night’s rest

Publication Date: October 2023 Source: Times of India

A recent advancement in the treatment of sleep apnea involves the use of neuro implants, which could potentially enhance the quality of sleep for those affected by this condition.

  • Neuro implants are designed to keep the airway open during sleep.
  • Clinical trials indicate promising results in reducing sleep apnea symptoms.
  • Doctors emphasize the importance of consulting with specialists to assess eligibility for this treatment.
“These implants could be a game-changer for patients who struggle with traditional CPAP machines.” - Dr. Smith, Sleep Specialist

The development of neuro implants presents a significant leap forward in addressing sleep apnea, potentially allowing many to experience a restful night's sleep without the discomfort of existing treatments.

item.title: Rotis made on direct flame can cause cancer? Here's what experts have to say - Deccan Herald
item.description:
Rotis made on direct flame can cause cancer? Here's what experts have to say

Published: 31 December 2024, 17:47 IST

Rotis are a staple in Indian households, but studies suggest that cooking them over a direct flame may pose health risks, potentially leading to cancer. Experts weigh in on the risks associated with this cooking method.

  • Cooking rotis involves placing dough on a hot pan followed by direct exposure to gas flames for puffing.
  • Research indicates that emissions from natural gas stoves are linked to health issues such as cancer and heart disease.
  • Pyrolysis during the cooking process may create carcinogenic compounds.
  • Experts note that harmful compounds like PAHs and HCAs are not likely produced unless cooking exceeds 15 minutes.
  • A well-ventilated kitchen and clean stove can mitigate health risks.
“Cancer risks of cooking roti on a gas hob have been overplayed so don’t panic,” said nutritionist Pallavi Pinge.

In conclusion, while there are potential risks, proper cooking methods and ventilation can reduce health concerns significantly.

item.title: ‘Dengue cases rise, seroprevalence remains lower in 2024’ - The Times of India
item.description:
Dengue Cases Rise, Seroprevalence Remains Lower in 2024

Publication Date: 2024
Source: Not specified

The article discusses the increase in dengue cases while noting that seroprevalence remains lower than expected for the year 2024.

  • The number of reported dengue cases has seen a significant rise.
  • Despite the rise in cases, seroprevalence levels have not increased correspondingly.
  • Health officials are monitoring the situation closely to prevent outbreaks.
“We must remain vigilant despite the lower seroprevalence.”

This situation highlights the need for continuous public health efforts to address mosquito-borne diseases.

item.title: 10 diet types you must adopt in 2025 for a healthy heart - The Times of India
item.description:
10 Diet Types You Must Adopt in 2025 for a Healthy Heart

Publication Date: Dec 31, 2024 | Source: TimesOfIndia.com

As we approach 2025, adopting heart-friendly diets will be crucial for maintaining cardiovascular health, reducing inflammation, lowering cholesterol, and promoting longevity.

  • Mediterranean diet: Reduces heart disease risk by promoting healthy cholesterol.
  • DASH Diet: Aims to lower blood pressure by focusing on fruits, vegetables, and whole grains.
  • Paleo diet: Emphasizes whole foods like lean meats and fruits while avoiding processed foods.
  • Low-carb, high-fiber diet: Helps keep blood sugar low and reduces heart disease risk.
  • Flexitarian diet: Primarily plant-based but allows occasional meat consumption.
  • Anti-inflammatory diet: Incorporates foods that reduce chronic inflammation.
  • Low-sodium diet: Focuses on fresh foods and limits high-sodium processed products.
  • Whole-food, plant-based diet: Focuses on whole foods while eliminating processed options.
  • Plant-based diet: Rich in fiber and antioxidants, protecting heart health.
  • Intermittent fasting: May lower blood pressure and cholesterol through a pattern of eating.
“These diets reduce inflammation, decrease cholesterol, and usually preserve the functionality of the heart.”

Adopting these diets in 2025 could significantly enhance heart health and overall well-being.

item.title: 5 warning signs of Vitamin B12 deficiency in your feet you shouldn't ignore - The Times of India
item.description:
5 Warning Signs of Vitamin B12 Deficiency in Your Feet

Publication Date: [Date not provided] Source: Times of India

The symptoms of Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to nerve damage and affect daily life. It's essential to recognize early signs to prevent irreversible damage.

  • Numbness and tingling in feet
  • Burning sensation in extremities
  • Difficulty walking or loss of balance
  • Pale or yellowish skin on feet
  • Persistent cold feet
“According to the National Institutes of Health (NIH), peripheral neuropathy caused by B12 deficiency can become irreversible if untreated.”

Recognizing these signs early can help in addressing Vitamin B12 deficiency and maintaining overall nerve health.

item.title: 5 Reasons Why Coffee Can Help You Live Longer, According to Science - EatingWell
item.description:
5 Reasons Why Coffee Can Help You Live Longer, According to Science

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Not specified

Many people wish to live long and healthy lives. While the fountain of youth has yet to be found, certain dietary and lifestyle choices can help keep your ticker ticking and your body working for a long time. Among these choices, coffee consumption has shown significant health benefits that may contribute to longevity.

  • May Help Manage a Healthy Weight: Caffeine intake can promote reductions in body fat and weight.
  • May Support Heart Health: Drinking 3 to 5 cups of coffee per day may reduce the risk of heart disease by 15%.
  • May Reduce Risk of Type 2 Diabetes: Coffee drinking is linked to a lower risk of developing type 2 diabetes.
  • May Help Protect from Certain Cancers: Coffee may reduce the risk of liver and endometrial cancers.
  • May Improve Cognitive Function and Mood: Caffeine has been shown to enhance cognitive function and may lower the risk of depression.
“Who doesn't want to live a long and healthy life? While there is no guarantee, there are some things you can do that may help keep that inevitable occurrence from happening too soon.”

The evidence suggests that moderate coffee consumption can provide several health benefits, potentially helping to prolong life.

item.title: Woman diagnosed with 'most painful condition known to medicine' shares unexpected first symptom - UNILAD
item.description:
Australian Woman Shares Initial Symptom of Severe Pain Condition

Published on December 31, 2022 by UNILAD

An Australian woman, Emily Morton, opened up about her diagnosis of atypical trigeminal neuralgia, described as the 'world's most painful condition', and the unexpected initial symptom of pain in her teeth.

  • Emily, from Adelaide, first noticed pain in her teeth in 2022.
  • Despite dental visits, no cause for the pain was found, which later spread to her entire face.
  • She experiences pain all over her body, unlike typical trigeminal neuralgia, which affects one side of the face.
  • Emily's condition has led to financial strain, with her family spending thousands on treatments and tests.
  • A new surgery offers some hope but comes with a high cost, leading to a GoFundMe page set up for Emily's treatment.
“It feels like a race against time to find out why. The condition has taken everything from me.”

Emily continues to search for treatment options while advocating for better support for those with invisible illnesses.
